body: As [GEODE-7600](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-7600) is resolved but didn't fix this test, changed Ignore description.

This pull request **fixes 1 alert** when merging 891a334b47940012ef2a330ceaa1db978009be03 into 5f7312a1be8c396a3344e8c6155ac388840c427f - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-4d790c2b07fc5219b351ba20eb7f574f8d866c25)

**fixed alerts:**

* 1 for Dereferenced variable may be null

> dschneider-pivotal 20 hours ago Member
If this is an SPI then this interface should dictate what the implementor needs to do. It already says you have to implement an "add" method etc. It s reasonable if we want to support exceptions from some of these methods to say so on the interface and then the implementer has to make sure and throw that type of exception. That would let the implementor explicitly say "I could not do an add for the following reason" and we could treat that as a handled exception. Other exceptions (like say an NPE caused by their coding error) could then be highlighted as unexpected. But with this code we have to treat all of them as unexpected and they end up with a big call stack in the log which is not needed if it is just something like "I did not have file system permissions".

I think I am trying to protect the system from any unhandled exceptions, even if it's NPE, since this is other people's code. this way, at least on our side, we logged it and know exactly what went wrong.
We'll want to keep an eye out for any weirdness or uptick in flakiness but from what I can tell, this change is good.
I'm closing this PR without merging it.  I'll use it as the basis for another branch to improve the SocketCreator interface.

Could you inform us when test scenario which is hanging, is provided. 
Just info, that test cases where updated due to these changes, as required by  "For all changes" checklist.

I will let you know and provide a jira tickets soon as a reproduction of
the issue is available.

Regarding updating tests, it's true that changes were made to test files,
but only those changes required for the code to compile successfully
following a change to a method signature. When adding new code to introduce
some new behaviour (a retry timeout for borrowConnection() in this case),
it's very important to write new tests to verify both that the desired
behaviour is actually present, and to verify that no unintended side
effects have been introduced.

note: the failures in the Tomcat9 tests are caused by an NPE Tomcat introduced in 9.0.21 as part of https://github.com/apache/tomcat/commit/f488fb08f8204126da79fd9d333c04d1ad936567

```
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.apache.catalina.session.StandardSession.setAttribute(StandardSession.java:1417)
	at org.apache.geode.modules.session.catalina.DeltaSession.localUpdateAttribute(DeltaSession.java:369)
	at org.apache.geode.modules.session.catalina.internal.DeltaSessionUpdateAttributeEvent.apply(DeltaSessionUpdateAttributeEvent.java:47)
```

According to the commit message, a Coverity scan told them they didn't need the null check anymore, maybe because StandardSession's only constructor requires a `manager` to be passed in.

However, our DeltaSession (which extends StandardSession) adds an empty constructor to initialize `manager` to `null`, which now guarantees setAttribute to always throw NPE.

yes, `./gradlew geode-assembly:distributedTest --tests Tomcat9Test` fails locally for me (even after gradle clean and blowing away my ~/.gradle caches).

> try explicitly adding rmiio to distributedTestRuntime

adding `distributedTestRuntimeOnly('com.healthmarketscience.rmiio:rmiio')` in `extensions/geode-modules-tomcat9/build.gradle` made no difference.  The tomcat class path must be composed somewhere else...

This pull request **introduces 1 alert** when merging f73a2efcaef7e263a3e210cf213300795e202d27 into 4b06a7ae04e3eb3e32d8a6a96c7eb5e5d3269df0 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-e8a372e1f8c3f1d7cbf1ebda42e08081b80c66eb)

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Dereferenced variable may be null

I have couple questions about this PR. The original JIRA says:

> The connection is left hanging (CLOSE-WAIT state). The peers are then unable to establish proper P2P communication later. 

Can you clarify what "unable to establish proper P2P communication later" means? If this is the actual bug, it would be nice to write a test that demonstrates how peers later cannot establish communications.

The test included with PR doesn't seem to test this case. It starts a locator and 3 servers. It then uses a test utility to "crash" the 3 servers. It then checks a connection count statistic, but it stops there. 

In addition, by crashing the 3 servers, the test is actually causing the locator to detect a network partition and shut itself down. So the test is actually testing a connection count on an object that is no longer really valid or in use.

From my understanding, the connection *should* already get cleaned up when the peer crashes or closes the connection by a couple of mechanisms:
* The *writer* thread may detect that the connection is closed and clean things up
* The membership system will notice a departed member and trigger cleanup of all of the connections to that member.

If there is a bug where we have problems connecting later, maybe it might involve fixing a problem with one of the above mechanisms? By introducing a third way to clean up the connection it seems like we might be introducing more possibilities for race conditions in maintaining the connection state.
@jmelchio
the change looks good. probably add a unit test?
The `distributedTest` failure seen here is addressed by https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-7842

Just to describe faulty scenario. In our network configuration, we have proxy between sites. So if some proxy resets connections, sender side will not detect that, because sender thread is terminated after handshake is finished. And there will be no reestablishing of connection, since sender do not know that connection is released.

This pull request **introduces 1 alert** when merging 9b849b7c6f5cd98f2b99a8e78275f55efa1ce716 into 2a3e09f2da4793d08d1124b5d5e656285295937d - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-2b2b22d92c0c3c3ad52ac45a9436a6704227edfd)

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Dereferenced variable may be null

> In our network configuration, we have proxy between sites.

This PR is changing peer-to-peer connections, not client server or WAN connections. Do you have a proxy between peers? Asking because I see other PRs related to WAN proxies.

> And there will be no reestablishing of connection, since sender do not know that connection is released.

This is what I'm not quite sure I understand here. I believe when a thread tries to send on this closed P2P socket, it should get an exception and retry, recreating the connection. This seems like what we need to be testing as part of this change - is there actually a problem sending another message if a proxy between the peers closes the socket?

Yes you are right. Proxy is between peers, and after proxy resets connections,  sender connection hangs in CLOSE-WAIT state. After that when sending any message over that connection, there is no exception. So our fix was to detect closing of sender connection.
@jmelchio

I think you may have found a different scenario where the result of a rebalance could be inconsistent. I think the issue I saw might have been caused by `RebalanceOperationPerformer.executeRebalanceOnDS`. On line 330 it returns rebalanceResult with success=false. Then on line 347 it returns rebalanceResult with success=true. Both times they have the same status message.
We might need some info level logging for the clear operation, even when there is no exception. So far, most of the log entries are debug level.
that IntegrationTestOpenJDK11 is a well-known flaky test outside this PR: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-7843?jql=text%20~%20%22testConcurrentHSetNX%22

What's the best way to coordinate changes to that page with this PR? Separate JIRA & PR, or add those changes to this PR?

I thought I would try to write the kind of test I was talking about so I could see this bug reproduce. It did reproduce the issue you described - https://github.com/Nordix/geode/pull/5.

I'm still looking into whether this is going to cause any race conditions, I'm a little worried that the Connection is left in a state of READING during this time, when the writer threads are also modifying the state.

> The code is somehow lacking in logging... Makes it REALLY hard to understand what is happening on the server WITHOUT stepping through code. Could we please add logging to `RenameExecutor`. Things like logger.info, logger.debug, logger.warn and logger.error are incredibly useful.

@kohlmu-pivotal, the redis commands all execute within this `ExecutionHandlerContext`.  The `ExecutionHandlerContext` logs all the inputs and then will also log any exceptions thrown.  I think that should make the `RenameExecutor` pretty debuggable

> I was really hoping that the inclusion of `swagger` as compileOnly was a debug mistake, and not something required to remove the warning on our side. Local testing shows that yes, we need Swagger for `compileOnly` to remove the warning :(

Yeah it turns out Swaggers annotations are runtime annotations so anything that loads our Swagger annotated classes need these annotations on the class path. If you look at the geode-core its implementation but optional. This is because we don't have this modularized and unless you are starting the REST interface you don't need Swagger. Once modularized this should clean up all the issues with downstream usage.

I guess I'm a bit confused here - won't an automatic rebase produce the same results as an automatic merge, if it is successful?

Is the issue really that rebase works and merge doesn't with this PR resource?

> I'm not sure this `PR` fully addresses the original JIRA ticket: if a member goes down or comes up **after** the rebalance operation finishes but **before** the output is shown to the user, the member count will still be incorrect, right?.

Hi @jujoramos , the output will represent on how much members rebalance command is executed. If some member go out or come back after command is finished and before output is shown it will print just num of members on which rebalance command is executed. So user can see that he has different number of members in the system and in the output of command and have a conclusion that rebalance command is not executed on all currently members in the system.
